title: Wednesday, 25th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

morning

PM11:01am

I guess we should have this chap.

PM11:02am

His official portrait

11:01 am
PM11:02am

PM11:02am

Xi Jinping

PM11:02am

What do we make of the new fangled Xi Jinping Thought for the New Era of Socialism With Chinese Special Characteristics

11:02 am
PM11:02am

??

PM11:03am

There's quite a gap between our cultures, that's for sure.

PM11:04am

Let me get you some Cap Economics on the matter

11:04 am
PM11:04am

As expected, Xi was able to stack China’s top leadership group with close allies. Furthermore, he left the
door open to staying on beyond 2022 by not anointing a successor. Unfortunately, there are few signs
that Xi plans to use his increased power to resolve China’s key structural problems. The only silver lining
is today’s promotion of key officials that favour greater reform, which offers a modicum of hope that
policy could shift in a more liberal direction in future as the flaws in Xi’s current agenda become clearer.

PM11:05am

The big news today is that Xi broke the norm of anointing a successor-in-waiting by placing a younger
politician in the role of First Secretary of the Secretariat. Instead, all four remaining PSC slots were filled
with officials that will, based on current retirement norms, be too old to take over from Xi in 2022.
• This doesn’t guarantee that Xi will stay on for a third term as General Secretary. Retirement norms could
always be broken or, just as Wen Jiabao became Premier in 2002 without having previously served in the
PSC, Xi could pass on the baton to a younger official from the politburo in 2022. That said, the lack of a
successor-in-waiting clearly leaves Xi’s options open and increases the likelihood that his reign will
extend well into the next decade

PM11:05am

Regardless of Xi’s succession plans, he has clearly succeeded in tightening his grip over the upper
echelons of the party. Xi has gone from having one close ally in the PSC, Wang Qishan, to having at least
three – Zhao Leji, Wang Huning and Li Zhanshu are known to be part of Xi’s inner circle. The historic
allegiances of the two other new PSC members, Wang Yang and Han Zheng, are less well documented.
But it may not matter at this stage. Yesterday’s elevation of Xi alongside Mao in the Party Constitution
made his dominance clear and so all PSC members are likely to fall in line.
• We’ve already discussed in earlier reports what this consolidation of power party might mean for the
economic outlook. But in brief, we think reduced political resistance will mean faster progress on
implementing Xi’s agenda, though we still believe this will fall short of resolving China’s most pressing
structural problems. (For more details see our Updates, “Xi is prioritising politics over market opening”
and “Xi enshrined in constitution, signalling his dominance”.)

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Admittedly, Xi’s agenda is not completely set in stone and the way in which policy priorities adjust in
response to economic events will be determined to some degree by the leanings of Xi’s top advisors.
Given this, it is reassuring to see that Wang Yang, believed to be part of the liberal wing of the party,
made it to the PSC. Likewise, it’s encouraging that Liu He, a key proponent of market reforms, was
promoted to the politburo. However, it remains to be seen to what degree they can help nudge policy
in the direction that is desperately needed – toward less state interference in the economy.

PM11:06am

Done on that.

PM11:06am

There's a clear desire on the right not to get stuck on China.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Ok. We are responsive to reader request

PM11:06am

sometimes

PM11:07am

Lloyds?

BE11:07am

11:08 am
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 68.00, up 0.6 (+0.89%), High: 68.23, Low: 65.54, Volume: 115.40m
BE11:08am

So sellside divi foreasts are drifting lower, but it looks like the buyside never really believed them.

BE11:09am

Let's get the CET1 ratio excitement out of the way.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

CET1 up 60bp qoq to 14.1%

BE11:11am

Or 85bp before divis, which is 60bp underlying capital generation, 5bp RWA movements and 20bp relating to other stuff.

BE11:12am

So, 2017 capital generation guidance gets bumped up to the top end of the previous forecast, to 225-240bp (then moderating back to run rate in future years)

11:12 am
BE11:12am

However!

BE11:13am

Pillar 2A goes from 2.5% to 3.0% and the PRA buffer is under review. Aren't bank earnings great? Isn't this all thrilling?

BE11:13am

Cutting to Barclays.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

This suggests upward pressure on the c13% CET1 target although it appears largely mitigated by the stronger capital generation in the year. IFRS 9 is currently expected to reduce the CET1 ratio by 10-30bps before any transitional relief, which looks broadly in line with expectations.

BE11:13am

Guidance on FY17 net interest margin is unchanged at 2.85%, which mechanically implies a 2.87% Q4 net interest margin despite the company indicating that the 2.90% in Q3 should be sustained in Q4. Similarly, FY17 cost of risk guidance of below 20bp indicates a Q4 charge of 31bp from 24bp in Q3.

BE11:13am

Reported PBT of £1951m is 5% below consensus but underlying PBT of £2,075m is 1% ahead of consensus with stronger net interest income more than offsetting higher provisions. Net interest margin is a positive at 2.90% (consensus 2.87%) and expected to be stable in Q4. Non interest income is 4% below consensus, resulting in revenue 1% ahead. Provisions are higher than expected with the Q3 charge equivalent to 24bp of loans and FY17 from 13bp in Q2.

Tangible book value increased 2% QoQ to 53.5p.

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Looking at the provisions there...Do we have a sense of who this large corporate bust is/was?

BE11:15am

Nope, not looked.

PM11:15am

Here, in the statement...

11:14 am
PM11:15am

The gross asset quality ratio remained unchanged at 26 basis points, reflecting strong asset quality and despite a single large corporate impairment in the third quarter and the impact of MBNA.

BE11:15am

Absolutely no idea. And will welcome speculation, of course.

BE11:16am

In the meantime, have Citi selling.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Reported CET1 ratio is +60bps qoq to 14.1%, well ahead of consensus and Citi expectations. This is driven by +30bps retained profit (helped by an absence of conduct charges in 3Q17, which we view as a timing issue more than anything else), +10bps RWA reduction, +20bps market movements & other. However IFRS 9 will be a 10-30bps hit to capital (before transition) and the bank has confirmed that it is seeing “upward pressure” on the Group’s capital requirement of c13%. Previously we argued that this would have to rise to c14%, due to the introduction of counter-cyclical buffers and a higher PRA buffer (due to the tougher consumer stress), but Lloyds has now also confirmed that Pillar 2A requirements are set to rise from 2.5% to 3.0%. Consequently we believe the Lloyds hurdle rate may now have to move towards c14.5%. This has severe implications for future dividends. Our DPS forecast is already well below consensus – for 2017 we see 3.5p (cons. 4.2p), 2018 3.5p (cons. 4.6p), 2019 4.5p (cons 5.0p).

BE11:16am

We expect to see negligible change to consensus EPS as FY17
consensus NIM is already at 2.84%, and loan loss ratio already at 18bps. However we do see a risk to consensus DPS, due to the higher capital requirements outlined by the company. We have a Sell rating, target price 61p.

BE11:17am

(@Rabble1: your screen's wrong.)

11:17 am
BE11:17am

And JP Morgan, saying the opposite.

PM11:17am

Bryce!

BE11:18am

With 50bps of CT1 equivalent to roughly 1.5p of DPS, we believe
that the group is well positioned to meet/exceed consensus DPS expectations for 2017 while still absorbing a potential rise in target CT1 to 14%. The shares trade at 9x 2018 PE and 1.2x P/TBAV for 13.2% RoNAV, we remain OW.

11:19 am

What? CET1 is 14.1%. T1 is 17.2.

BE11:20am

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Here's RBC, who reckons things are going fine.

BE11:26am

In Q3/17 deposits and lending experienced double digit growth,
and Metro’s loan-to-deposit ratio increased to 80% for the first time. This resulted in Metro’s fifth quarter of underlying profitability. Metro confirms 2020 guidance and our forecasts are little changed; price target remains 4000p. Although we maintain our Sector Perform rating, we still believe that Metro is a long-term, high growth, low risk story.

BE11:27am

Bit more of that .....

11:27 am
BE11:27am

In Q3/17 Metro opened its 50th store and marked its 7th birthday since its launch. Deposits and lending experienced double digit growth, and Metro’s loan-to-deposit ratio increased to 80% for the first time. This resulted in Metro’s fifth quarter of underlying profitability. Regarding its outlook, Metro confirmed its 2020 guidance. Our EPS forecasts are little changed (no more than 1p in each year of our forecast horizon). For 2017E, we reduce our EPS forecast by 1p, increase it by 1p in both 2018E and 2019E, and maintain it in 2020E. We make some improvement to our model drivers (higher loan to deposit ratio, more gradual increase in the cost of risk, improvement in deposit gathering) while we account for some deterioration in other model drivers (slower new store openings, lower NIM + fees, more gradual improvement in the cost income ratio). The net result of the above changes is to largely reaffirm our total income forecasts (which still call for a 2016A-2020E CAGR of 41%) and 2020E EPS forecast (which remains 213p). Our price target remains 4000p. It is our opinion that Metro’s growth trajectory should continue at high levels at least through the mid-2020s

BE11:27am

Our 4000p price target values Metro at 19x 2020E EPS, a multiple we find appropriate given the company’s unique characteristics.

BE11:28am

19x 2020 for a high street bank that's opening branches, rather than selling them to Wetherspoons. I dunno.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Numis don't like, FWIW.

BE11:29am

While total Q3 revenues increased 46% YoY to £78m (+5% vs. NSe: £74m), underlying PBT of £7.2m (Q316: £0.6m) was c.26% below the £9.7m we were forecasting for the period. This appears to have been largely driven by an unexplained 34% YoY increase in operating expenses during the year to £70m which was c.14% higher than our estimate of £61m. In our view, this is going to make it very challenging for the Group to achieve both our (£28m) and consensus’ (£29m) FY2017 PBT numbers and we therefore expect to downgrade our estimates by c.5-10%. The Group has also announced that the Group CFO Mike Brierly will be retiring next year and, subject to regulatory approval, will be replaced by David Arden who is currently CFO of Sainsbury’s Bank. So despite further strong deposit and loan growth, we remain concerned about Metro’s need to maintain such rapid growth during a period in which asset yields are falling, banks are relaxing credit standards and macro data is weakening. In our view, Metro’s 2020E valuation of c.3x TNAV implies the Group significantly exceeds all of its 2020 targets, something we find difficult to visualise given the increased uncertainty post-Brexit, weakening macro data and rising competition. We therefore maintain our target price of 2,000p and SELL recommendation.

BE11:30am

Okay, so where is Metro's deposit growth coming from?

11:30 am
PM11:30am

I don't know. We've been skeptic and wrong since day one on this

BE11:30am

Bank deposits, famously, are very sticky. That's why First Direct and the likes offer you £100 to switch.

BE11:31am

And the ones growing are the ones that offer online whizzy stuff and are called Pebble, or Beige, or Helium or whatever.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

But Metro? Who's switching to Metro, and why? Don't get it.

BE11:33am

Drax mentioned some time ago. Not sure if that's apropos of much.

11:33 am
Drax Group PLC (DRX:LSE): Last: 281.30, down 5.7 (-1.99%), High: 290.00, Low: 279.90, Volume: 240.75k
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:33am

Have that anyway.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Drax has de-rated (-23% YTD) and now trades on dividend yield. At the same time, underlying drivers for Drax have begun to move up. Our EBITDA estimates rise by c6% in 2017E and c2% in 2019E on our new commodity price forecasts, albeit our EPS estimates fall by c16-45% across 2017E-19E on front-end loading amortisation of the Opus acquisition. Our TP falls to 370p/sh (from 400p) reflecting lower coal-fired running post-2020. We see Drax as cheap.

BE11:34am

Lead indicators for profitability have moved up: Gas, power and
renewable obligation certificate prices have increased across the past 3, 6 and 12 months. Our 2017-19E EBITDA forecasts are achievable on current power prices. Indicators of biomass costs—freight and USD/GBP—have not moved by as much. We note that +£5/MWh on spreads would be +c£80m on EBITDA; (2) Growth plans ‘free’ upside potential: Drax has a target to reach greater than £425m EBITDA by 2025 (from £238m in 2017E) through investments in new generation and growth in pelletisation/supply. Most of Drax’s growth plans rely upon capacity payments of c£25/KW-yr, but Drax has advantaged projects that should be able to win payments. We do not include these in our forecasts until Drax wins the capacity payments and gets FID, in line with our sector-wide approach. If it were to re-invest, it could generate +c30p/share of value not reflected in our TP; and (3) Cash flow generation and dividends: If Drax cannot invest, we would expect it to return cash to shareholders. Drax still has a c14% 2019-23E FCF yield to equity and a c4.3% 2017E divi yield, rising to c5.8% by 2023E (c12.3p/share in 2017E, growing from thereon) and this is all cash. The company is only paying out c30% of the FCF to equity.

PM11:35am

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 343.60, down 1.1 (-0.32%), High: 345.80, Low: 341.00, Volume: 2.63m
PM11:39am

https://www.ft.com...-9021-d5cf068be379

A senior figure in Marks & Spencer’s troubled clothing division has left the company less than a month after starting in the new role that had been created for her, striking a blow to the company’s plans to turn around the business as it prepares for the key Christmas trading season.

Jo Jenkins, M&S’ former director of womenswear, lingerie and beauty, moved to an expanded role as clothing and beauty director at the start of this month, to support the newly-arrived managing director Jill McDonald. Ms McDonald was previously chief executive of FTSE 250 retailer Halfords, but has no direct experience in the fashion sector.

11:39 am
PM11:39am

However, Sky News reported on Wednesday morning that Ms Jenkins had resigned from the company to become the chief executive of White Stuff, the privately-owned clothing retailer.

11:43 am
Patisserie Holdings PLC (CAKE:LSE): Last: 347.25, down 2.75 (-0.79%), High: 351.00, Low: 345.00, Volume: 19.77k
BE11:45am

This is part of a massive travel and leisure sector thing that covers everything from pubs to ten-pin bowling.

PM11:46am

And cakes

11:45 am
BE11:46am

We believe the key to investing in Leisure is finding the cost mitigation, LFL sales potential (through market positioning, pricing power, scope to diversify revenue streams or refurbishment opportunities) and acquisition firepower to offset rising costs. The key is picking the right sub-sectors; the ones that can grow and embrace technology without attracting over-supply. The historically neglected sub-sectors of bowling and low-cost gyms are generating the highest levels of innovation, returns and growth, through embracing technology and assisted by higher barriers to successful entry.

BE11:46am

We believe the opposite is true of the restaurant sub-sector.

BE11:46am

So ........

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Bowling market demand is growing at c6% pa even though there is no supply growth. All the demand growth is being driven by the leading two operators, Hollywood Bowl and Ten Entertainment#, which are expanding and generating LFL sales growth, providing a substantially superior offering to that provided by a large number of independent operators.

BE11:47am

Cinema market. Since 2002, there has been no growth in cinema market admissions despite the number of screens growing at a CAGR of 2%, albeit with big short term fluctuations that largely reflect the quality of film releases. However, spend per head and total box office have grown at a CAGR of 4%, largely as a result of investment in premium product.

BE11:47am

The branded five-a-side soccer market, like cinemas, has had to cope with rapid growth in a cheaper alternative. Huge growth in non-commercial pitches contributed to the branded 3G operators ceasing expansion in 2014 and focusing investment on premium product. Goals Soccer Centres is leading the way with its Arena and Clubhouse 2020 programmes.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Gym market. Almost all the gym market’s demand growth is being driven by four low-cost operators making health and fitness clubs affordable to a large share of the population for the first time. We forecast that their strong growth can continue for at least another eight years without requiring much growth in market penetration (due to taking share from traditional and public gyms).

BE11:48am

Pub market. The supply/demand dynamics of the pub market are more attractive than that of the restaurant sector. With drinking out recovering, the managed pub sector is now more active at repositioning assets away from value towards premium brands than from drink to food. Overall, the quoted operators have above-average exposure to premium venues and to London.
• Pub drink price increases are correlated to the current price level, implying that premium priced venues have less price-sensitive customers. In both pubs and restaurants, the premium segment is outperforming in relation to pricing and volumes.
• Tenanted pubs are performing at least as well as managed pubs. Managed pub LFL sales rose by 0.9% on average (1.8% in London; 0.6% outside London) in the year to September 2017 (Coffer Peach Tracker). In comparison, the quoted tenanted operators generated average LFL net income growth of 2.3% during the last year.

BE11:48am

Restaurant demand and supply growth is slowing, with large operators cutting back on expansion and independents likely to contract in size. As with pubs, premium venues are outperforming in the restaurant sector. However, for the sector as a whole, LFL sales are minimal vs c3% being needed to offset costs, with limited scope to mitigate costs and diversify revenue.

Overall, managed restaurant LFL sales rose 0.3% (0.1% in London; 0.4% outside London) in the year to September 2017 (Coffer Peach Tracker). Somehow, independent restaurant numbers rose in H1 2017; we view this as being unsustainable.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

But you'll be wanting the logic for upgrading a fairly bad cake shop, I guess.

BE11:49am

Patisserie Holdings is a leading operator in the branded bakery
market, which MCA predicts will grow sales by 3.6% this year
vs a 1.4% increase in outlets. We expect the company to
continue to grow average sales and margins, and generate surplus cash flow from its high return model. In our view, the biggest uncertainty is whether the company can find a suitable acquisition to spend its growing cash pile on.

PM11:50am

Phew

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Expansion rate of 20 new outlets pa for Patisserie, in case you're wondering.

BE11:50am

BE11:52am

Will note in passing that they opened in Dundee and most of the locals went, "three bloody fifty for a slice of cake michty me!" and went to Wallace's on the Perth Road instead.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Good on them

BE11:52am

Still, Dundee might be the exception. It is in many ways.

undefined
11:52 am
PM11:52am

On the subject of firms which plaster our streets with identical stuff

PM11:52am

Like coffee shops and plastic hotels

PM11:53am

Whitbread still under pressure

11:53 am
Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 3,711, down 41.89 (-1.12%), High: 3,742, Low: 3,683, Volume: 404.90k
PM11:53am

I think it was Morgan Stanley that I mentioned the other day as suggesting we could have another 600 Costas

BE11:53am

Did I see a MOST downgrade earlier?

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Yeah

PM11:54am

A very reluctant downgrade

PM11:54am

Plenty to like from Whitbread's results … The company exceeded H1 expectations with 7% PBT growth (see our 1st Take here), confirmed its expansion plans are on track along with visibly high returns (H1 group ROCE +30bps), talked about increasing its £150m efficiency programme (£60m already achieved), and delivered a solid turnaround in its International markets ("nearing a tipping point"). One specific detail was also encouraging – the company's disclosure that RevPAR grew by 3.3% in catchments with no Premier Inn capacity growth, in-line with the market. this implies RevPAR fell by only 1% in catchments where it added rooms, an attractive trade-off given capacity grew by 19% in these markets. Management were fairly upbeat, if wary of the economic uncertainty, and we think the team is doing all the right things in terms of balancing innovation (new brands and products) with cost control (mainly back of house).

11:54 am
PM11:54am

… and while we think this is an attractive company … Premier Inn's single brand, single market, owned/leased structure is not in vogue, but this structure has created arguably the "best" listed hotel chain globally, with an occupancy rate exceeding 80%, TripAdvisor score of 4.4, an OTA mix of just 5%, a unit growth rate of 7%, and a 65% freehold mix. Costa is by far the largest coffee chain in the UK and the second largest globally, offers upside from its new product and technology improvements, and is seeing rapid expansion not just in the UK but also overseas (see here and here). Overall we forecast Whitbread will generate a FY17-20e CAGR of 8% for both sales and EPS (nearly all from expansion rather than LfL growth), leading to a company trading on a cal 2020 P/E of 11.5x and EV/EBITDA of 7.5x. Our sum-of-the-parts values the shares at £45, 20% above the current share price.

PM11:55am

Premier Inn the "best listed hotels group globally"??

PM11:55am

MOST accept that investors are focused on weak like for likes

11:55 am
BE11:56am

BE11:56am

BE11:56am

That kind of thing.

11:56 am
PM11:56am

So there's room in Wales and Scotland

BE11:57am

BE11:58am

BE11:58am

11:59 am
